Award.AwardTitle: CER: openHTML, a Scaffolded Web Development Tool to Support Elementary Computational Literacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Drexel University, together with partners at Mozilla Foundation and the University of Nebraska at Omaha, will investigate the impact of beginning web development experiences on learners' mastery and perceptions of computational skills and concepts. Using introductory web editors open HTML and Thimble in both formal and informal settings; they will engage beginners who have little or no experience with creative computation in constructing their first web pages and learning HTML and CSS. They will conduct observational studies paired with testing to understand learners' experiences with web development and identify activity patterns that signal recurring errors, recoveries, misconceptions and competencies and will use these findings to identify markers of error and competency in beginner's code.

Widespread computational competency is a vital component of a competitive workforce and vibrant economy. By lowering the barriers to comfort and competence with computing, this project aims to 1) engage individuals who may not otherwise appear on the computer science education radar in creative computational activities 2) improve the tools available to web development educators and learners and 3) extend scientific knowledge about the development of early computational thinking skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational literacy is a goal associated with grand visions of public reform. Educational pioneers such as Alan Kay and Seymour Papert were inspired by the vision of a world in which every person wields computation as a tool for personal expression and enrichment, civic action, and creativity. In this project, researchers from Drexel University, University of Nebraska, and Mozilla Foundation partnered to help move toward the vision of universal computational literacy. We pursued this goal through the development of innovative learning interventions and tools for beginning web developers to help them explore “web building” as a form of creative and collaborative computation.

The outcomes of this project include both contributions to the research literature through published studies as well as contributions to the general public in the form of free educational tools that have been made available online. Over the life of the project, we progressed from early, detailed studies of students in classrooms to later, large-scale studies using data from the online tools that our team developed. A chronology of these learning environments and scholarly outcomes are summarized below:

Early in the project, our multi-institutional team developed a new web development tool called openHTML.  This tool allowed novices to edit web pages without hiding the computational complexity from them as many editing tools do.  In an early description of the design approach published as an extended abstract at the prestigious SIGCHI conference, we characterized the openHTML tool as a “transitional design”— support that fades through disuse when the learner no longer needs it or wants to accomplish tasks that require a more sophisticated tool.

To understand how novices learned computational concepts in this environment, we conducted lab experiments, observed children using it in an after school program, and developed educational materials and integrated it into college web development courses for non-computer science majors. In a parallel thread, we developed a web-based game building environment called Web Jumper and used it in a series of summer camps to support young people in learning web development. These studies were published at the International Computing Education Research conference, Interaction Design and Children, and ACM Transactions on Computing Education. 

Throughout these studies, we learned that novices have particular difficulty understanding hierarchies and inheritance, which are fundamental aspects of web coding. Our next step was to develop a research instrument called Nester that would allow us to observe how learners deal with nesting in different task conditions. This work was published and presented at the Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education. 

Because the web is an open environment where anyone can build and contribute, we were interested not only in controlled experimentation and classroom deployment but also in developing public tools. Toward this end, we developed
    1. a Wordpress plug in called SnowBall that makes it easy for journalists and bloggers to create modern, immersive articles as seen by world-class news organizations and give them an opportunity to learn about computation by accessing and modifying the underlying html and css.
     2. Web development games called Flexbox Froggy and Grid Garden that challenges people to learn specific CSS layout modules. A study of learning trajectories in Flexbox Froggy was published at the SIGCSE Technical Symposium (Special Interest Group in Computer Science Education.

Concurrent with these efforts, Mozilla’s team developed the Thimble web editing environment, and we continue to analyze data generated by Thimble learners.

At the time this grant ended, educational tools that were created and made available to the public by the research team have already been used by many tens of thousands of people online and analysis of learner-generated data from these tools continues.
